# Gopuram

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Madurai_Meenakshi_temple_2.jpg/220px-
Madurai_Meenakshi_temple_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madurai_Meenakshi_temple_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Madurai_Meenakshi_temple_2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Meenakshiamman Temple](/wiki/Meenakshiamman_Temple "Meenakshiamman Temple")
tower in [Madurai](/wiki/Madurai "Madurai")

A **Gopuram** or **gopura** ([Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit_language "Sanskrit
language"): गोपुरम्, _gopuram_) is a monumental [gatehouse](/wiki/Gatehouse
"Gatehouse") tower, usually ornate, at the entrance of a [Hindu
temple](/wiki/Hindu_temple "Hindu temple"), in the [Dravidian
architecture](/wiki/Dravidian_architecture "Dravidian architecture") of the
[Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu "Tamil Nadu"), [Andhra
Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh"), [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala
"Kerala"), [Karnataka](/wiki/Karnataka "Karnataka"), and
[Telangana](/wiki/Telangana "Telangana") states of [Southern
India](/wiki/Southern_India "Southern India").[1] Ancient and early medieval
temples feature smaller gopuram, while in later temples they are a prominent
feature of [Hindu temples](/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture "Hindu temple
architecture") of the [Dravidian style](/wiki/Tamil_architecture "Tamil
architecture");[2] or in many cases the temple compound was expanded and new
larger gopuram built along the new boundary. They are topped by the
_[kalasam](/wiki/Kalasam "Kalasam")_ , a bulbous stone [finial](/wiki/Finial
"Finial"). They function as gateways through the walls that surround the
temple complex.[3]

The gopuram's origins can be traced back to early structures of the
[Pallava](/wiki/Pallavas "Pallavas") kings, and relate to the central
[shikhara](/wiki/Shikhara "Shikhara") towers of North India. Between the
twelfth and sixteenth century, during the [Pandya](/wiki/Pandya "Pandya"),
Nayaka and Vijayanagara era when Hindu temples increasingly became a hub of
the urban life, these gateways became a dominant feature of a temple's outer
appearance, eventually overshadowing the inner sanctuary which became obscured
from view by the gopuram's colossal size and courtyards.[4] It also dominated
the inner sanctum in amount of ornamentation. Often a shrine has more than one
gopuram.[1] They also appear in architecture outside India, especially [Khmer
architecture](/wiki/Khmer_architecture "Khmer architecture"), as at [Angkor
Wat](/wiki/Angkor_Wat "Angkor Wat").

A large Dravidian-style temple, or koil, may have multiple gopurams as the
openings into successively smaller walled enclosures around the main shrine,
with the largest generally at the outer edges. The temple compound is
typically square or rectangular with at least the outermost wall having
gopuras, often from the four cardinal directions. The multiple storeys of a
gopuram typically repeat the lower level features on a rhythmic diminishing
scale.[4] The inner sanctum and its towering roof (the central deity's shrine)
is also called the _[Vimanam (shrine)](/wiki/Vimana_\(architectural_feature\)
"Vimana \(architectural feature\)")_ , although in the south it is typically
smaller than the gopurams in large temples.

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gopuram&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/1834_sketch_of_elements_in_Hindu_temple_architecture%2C_single_storey_gopura.jpg/161px-1834_sketch_of_elements_in_Hindu_temple_architecture%2C_single_storey_gopura.jpg)](/wiki/File:1834_sketch_of_elements_in_Hindu_temple_architecture,_single_storey_gopura.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/1834_sketch_of_elements_in_Hindu_temple_architecture%2C_two_storey_gopura.jpg/150px-1834_sketch_of_elements_in_Hindu_temple_architecture%2C_two_storey_gopura.jpg)](/wiki/File:1834_sketch_of_elements_in_Hindu_temple_architecture,_two_storey_gopura.jpg)

A gopura is a monumental gate, usually ornate with odd number of _kalasa_ on
top. It may have one or many storeys. Left: Single storey gopura; Right: Two
storey gopura.

The [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language "Tamil language") derivation is from the two
words: கோ (kō) and புறம் (puram) meaning 'king' and 'exterior'
respectively.[5] It originates from the [Sangam age](/wiki/Sangam_age "Sangam
age") when it was known as ஓங்கு நிலை வாயில் (ōnggu nilai vāyil) meaning
'imperishable gateway'.[6]

An alternative derivation is from the [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit")
word _gopuram_ , which can be broken down to _go_
([Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit_language "Sanskrit language"): गो), which means
either 'a city' or 'a cow', and _[puram](/wiki/Pur_\(Vedic\) "Pur \(Vedic\)")_
([Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit_language "Sanskrit language"): पुरम्), 'a town', or
'a settlement'.[7]

## Architecture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gopuram&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Architecture")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Gopuram_Madras.jpg/220px-
Gopuram_Madras.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gopuram_Madras.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gopuram_Madras.jpg "Enlarge")

Detail of a gopuram at [Chennai](/wiki/Chennai "Chennai")

A gopuram is usually a tapering [oblong](/wiki/Rectangle "Rectangle") in form
with ground-level wooden doors, often richly decorated, providing access.
Above is the tapering or ["battered"](/wiki/Batter_\(walls\) "Batter
\(walls\)") gopuram, divided into many storeys which diminish in size as the
gopuram tower narrows. Usually the tower is topped with a [barrel
vaulted](/wiki/Barrel_vault "Barrel vault") roof with a finial.[4] The form
began rather modestly in the 10th century, as at [Shore
Temple](/wiki/Shore_Temple "Shore Temple"), [Mamallapuram](/wiki/Mamallapuram
"Mamallapuram"), with the 11th century [Brihadeeswarar
Temple](/wiki/Brihadeeswarar_Temple "Brihadeeswarar Temple") in
[Thanjavur](/wiki/Thanjavur "Thanjavur") marking a crucial step forward with
two multi-storey gopurams from that period, much larger than any earlier ones,
though much smaller than the main tower (vimanam) of the temple. The four
gopurams of the [Thillai Nataraja Temple,
Chidambaram](/wiki/Thillai_Nataraja_Temple,_Chidambaram "Thillai Nataraja
Temple, Chidambaram") are important early examples, begun in the mid-13th
century but completed over a longer period.[8] Gopurams are exquisitely
decorated with sculpture and carvings and painted with a variety of themes
derived from the [Hindu mythology](/wiki/Hindu_mythology "Hindu mythology"),
particularly those associated with the presiding [deity](/wiki/Deity "Deity")
of the temple where the gopuram is located.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The two tallest gopuras are both modern, at least in part. The
[Ranganathaswamy Temple, Srirangam](/wiki/Ranganathaswamy_Temple,_Srirangam
"Ranganathaswamy Temple, Srirangam"), [Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu "Tamil
Nadu"), has 21 _[gopurams](/wiki/Gopurams "Gopurams")_ (tower gateways),
including the towering 239.5-foot (73.0 m) _Rajagopuram_ (shrine of the main
gateway), which is claimed as the tallest temple tower in Asia. The 73-metre
(240 ft)-tall 13-tiered _Rajagopuram_ was completed in 1987 (having previously
been incomplete) and dominates the landscape for kilometers around, while the
remaining 20 gopurams were built between the 14th and 17th centuries.[9]
Competing for the title of "tallest" is the twenty storey 249-foot (76 m)
gopura at the modern [Murdeshwar](/wiki/Murdeshwar "Murdeshwar") Temple,
which, unusually, is provided with a [lift](/wiki/Elevator "Elevator").[10]
